On Thu, 30 Jan 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> I want to see the full strings in a ComparisonFailure if they are no
> more than 40 characters long enough.
>
> I want to know at which character index the first difference occurs.
>
> If the strings are long (> 40 characters), I want at least 10
> characters of context on either side of the beginning of the
> difference.

This sort of ties in to something I've been thinking about for a while.

Why does a TestCase inherit all of its assertion routines?

I found a while back that I wanted to be able to set up some general
parameters for my assertions before I used them, and continue to use
those parameters over and over again. The first time this happened, I
needed to insert the current date and time into a column in a database
table. I didn't need much accuracy, and wanted to save some space in
a multi-million row table, so I was using an MS SQL server date type
that was smaller (4 bytes instead of eight, I recall) but accurate only
down to several seconds. So at any particular point, if I inserted
the current time, the time coming back out of the database would be
different than what I'd inserted, though always certainly less than a
minute or so different.

So what I did was create a separate DateAssertion object that took,
in the constructor, a parameter saying just how different the two Date
objects could be and still be "equal" for my purposes. Then I'd invoke
the DateAssertion's assert() method.

It seems to me one could just as well make a StringAssertion object that
one could set up with appropriate parameters so that you'd get output,
when an assertion fails, that's more appropriate for your particular
circumstance.

That led me to start thinking about whether it might not be cleaner and
simpler, overall, to completely separate the assertion code from the test
cases by using separate assertion objects for everything.
